intro: Jacobaea reclinata, commonly known as the drooping tansy, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of ray and disk florets. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped, gray-green leaves that are covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are yellow and bloom from late summer to autumn, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Jacobaea reclinata is often found in meadows, woodland edges, and disturbed soils, and it has a somewhat aromatic scent.
